bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, October 5, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 79. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, October 5, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. The prospects of an early settlement of the claim of Miss Winifred Miller, against the Liberian Government, very doubtful
No. 79. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, October 5, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say that referring to my No. 73, Consular, of June 4, 1901, I informed the Department that the claim of Miss Winifred Miller, heir of the late M. Miller, against the Liberian Government for a balance of Four Hundred Fifty six 59/100 Dollars represented by the Hon. C. E. Littlefield; an order for which had been drawn by F. O. Thorne,

in my favor, upon Hon. A. Barclay, Secretary of the Treasury, which order, had been accepted by him, and that in an interview with the President (who is de facto Secretary of State) upon the subject of settlement, he informed me that the order would be paid early in the beginning of the July quarter 1901. After the departure of the Secretary of the Treasury, for England, without having made payment, thereof. I dispatched my No 24, Miscellaneous, of July 11, 1901, to the Acting Secretary of State relative to the matter of payment Enclosed see the reply of the Acting Secretary of the Treasury July 25, 1901, to the Secretary of State; and
and of the Secretary of State July 29, 1901, to me touching this matter.

The Honorable Arthur Barclay, returned September 17, 1901, before the end of the Liberian fiscal year, September 30th the time that the Acting Secretary of the Treasury that arrangements and a settlement would be made. According I called at the State Department September 18, 1901, in person, and called up my No. 24, Miscellaneous, of July 11, 1901, and requested the Secretary of State to see the Secretary of the Treasury and arrange for a settlement of said claim by the close of the quarter September 30, 1901. In reply he assured me an early reply, the which I have
have not yet received.

Having had several interviews with the President, relative to the settlement of this claim, who had stated two difinite times, when said amount should be paid, I incidentally met him at the Executive Mansion, Tuesday September 24, 1901, and called his attention to the fact that I had not heard from my request of September 18, 1901, through the State Department, and asked that he would be so kind, as to have the matter attended to before the close of the quarter. He again assured me that he would have an interview with the Secretary of the Treasury during the day; a cabinet meeting, Thursday September 26,

26, 1901, and would have the matter attended to by Friday, September 27, 1901. Hearing no more from him, touching this matter, on Saturday morning, September 28, 1901. I dispatched to him, direct my No. 39, Miscellaneous relative to the matter and has there far failed to receive a reply, from either the President or the Secretary of State, touching this matter. I am impressed to believe that they have no intention of a settlement of said claim, short of some peremtory; strong and direct demand from the Department of State, Washington. I have the awaiting your advice and further instructions, I have the honor to be your obedient servant;
servant,
Owen L. W. Smith Consul General, Inclosures as above refered to
No. 24/1901 Miscellaneous Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, July 11, 1901.

Sir: I have the honor to inform you that I hold in my possession for collection from the Liberian Government an order upon the Secretary of Treasury for Four Hundred Fifty-six 45/100 Dollars in Audited Liberian Government Bills. The Secretary of the Treasury having accepted the order, without delivering the Bills, His Excellency the President informed me sometime since that said order would be honored soon after the close of the June quarter 1901;
You will confer a favor, if you will kindly see the proper authorities arrange for an early settlement of said account, and kindly notify me when to present same for payment Awaiting
Awaiting your reply;
I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith Consul General.
Department of State, Monroia Liberia, July 15, 1901.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your communication No. 24, of the 11th inst, informing me that you have in your possession an order on the Secretary of the Treasury for Four hudred fifty-six dollars 45/100 ($456.45) Audited Liberian Government Bills, and asking me to confer with the proper authorities in order to have an early settlement of same.
In reply I have to inform you that I will submit the matter to the proper authorities, and hope that I will be able to forward you an early reply.
I have the honor to be Sir, Yours obediently, W. V. Gibson Acting Secretary of State; Hon. Owen L. W. Smith U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General
Department of State, Monrovia, July 29, 1901.
Sir: Referring to my conversation of July 15th inst. I have the honor to forward you herewith enclosed, a letter from the Secretary of Treasury, which will explain itself.
I have the honor to be Sir; your obedient servant, W. V. Gibson, Acting Secretary of State.
Hon. O. L. W. Smith U.S. Minister Resident U.S. Legation Monrovia.
